The Fohns Hopkins University does not discriminate on the basis of race, color; sex,
religion, sexual orientation, national or ethnic origin, age, disability or veteran status in
any student program or activity administered by the university or with regard to
admission or employment. Defense Department discrimination in ROTC programs on the
basis of sexual orientation conflicts with this university policy. The university is committed
to encouraging a change in the Defense Department policy.

The Johns Hopkins University
century and a quarter ago, Johns Hopkins,
a son of Quaker tobacco farmers who
raised himself from grocer’s helper to
millionaire financier, performed an act of generos-
ity unprecedented in both size and impact.

He provided in his will—with a bequest of
$7 million, then the largest private donation of
any kind in the United States—for the founding
of a university and hospital that transformed
higher education in America and the practice of
medicine worldwide.

Hopkins’ gift led to the creation in Baltimore
of a new model for the pursuit of scholarship,
teaching and patient care together in a single
place. The university’s first president, Daniel Coit
Gilman, was determined it would do more than
just impart the wisdom of the ages to its students.
Instead, faculty and students at Hopkins would
work together to make new discoveries, to create
new knowledge.

Johns Hopkins was the first Am-
erican research university, and
today, it remains an interna-
tional leader in the arts,
the humanities, the social
sciences, the natural
sciences and tech-
nology as well as in
medicine, public
health and nursing.

The university is at
work around the world

—and, in fact, deep

into space—making new discoveries, putting that
knowledge to work for humanity and preparing
the next generation of scholars, scientists,

caregivers and professionals.

The Homewood campus
oday, The Johns Hopkins University has a
campus in Washington, D.C., the Applied
Physics Laboratory in Howard County,
Md., continuing education facilities throughout
the Baltimore-Washington area and major centers
in Nanjing, China, and Bologna and Florence,
Italy. But it remains rooted in Baltimore, with
three major campuses and a downtown continuing
education center in the city of its birth. It is the
city’s largest private employer.
Homewood, in northern Baltimore, is
home to the university’s administration and to the
Krieger School of Arts and Sciences, the Whiting
School of Engineering and the School of
Continuing Studies. About 3,500 of the university’s
4,100 full-time undergraduates study here,
as do about 1,400 of its 4,200 full-time
graduate students.
Homewood is also the site of
the Milton S. Eisenhower
Library, the university’s
primary research library.
Located on or near the
campus are a number of
important university centers,
including the Johns Hopkins
University Press, the Institute
for Policy Studies, the Krieger

The Johns Hopkins University
century and a quarter ago, Johns Hopkins,
a son of Quaker tobacco farmers who
raised himself from grocer’s helper to
millionaire financier, performed an act of generos-
ity unprecedented in both size and impact.

He provided in his will—with a bequest of
$7 million, then the largest private donation of
any kind in the United States—for the founding
of a university and hospital that transformed
higher education in America and the practice of
medicine worldwide.

Hopkins’ gift led to the creation in Baltimore
of a new model for the pursuit of scholarship,
teaching and patient care together in a single
place. The university’s first president, Daniel Coit
Gilman, was determined it would do more than
just impart the wisdom of the ages to its students.
Instead, faculty and students at Hopkins would
work together to make new discoveries, to create
new knowledge.

Johns Hopkins was the first Am-
erican research university, and
today, it remains an interna-
tional leader in the arts,
the humanities, the social
sciences, the natural
sciences and tech-
nology as well as in
medicine, public
health and nursing.

The university is at
work around the world

—and, in fact, deep

into space—making new discoveries, putting that
knowledge to work for humanity and preparing
the next generation of scholars, scientists,

caregivers and professionals.

The Homewood campus
oday, The Johns Hopkins University has a
campus in Washington, D.C., the Applied
Physics Laboratory in Howard County,
Md., continuing education facilities throughout
the Baltimore-Washington area and major centers
in Nanjing, China, and Bologna and Florence,
Italy. But it remains rooted in Baltimore, with
three major campuses and a downtown continuing
education center in the city of its birth. It is the
city’s largest private employer.
Homewood, in northern Baltimore, is
home to the university’s administration and to the
Krieger School of Arts and Sciences, the Whiting
School of Engineering and the School of
Continuing Studies. About 3,500 of the university’s
4,100 full-time undergraduates study here,
as do about 1,400 of its 4,200 full-time
graduate students.
Homewood is also the site of
the Milton S. Eisenhower
Library, the university’s
primary research library.
Located on or near the
campus are a number of
important university centers,
including the Johns Hopkins
University Press, the Institute
for Policy Studies, the Krieger
